fidler-large-HBCA-E3-2-225.title: "An Indian Map of the Different Tribes that inhabit on the East & West Side of the Rocky Mountains with all the rivers & other remarkbl. places, also the number of Tents etc. Drawn by the Feathers or Ac ko mok ki -- a Black foot chief -- 7th Feby. 1801 -- reduced 1/4 from the Original Size -- by Peter Fidler."
fidler-large-HBCA-E3-2-225.artist: Peter Fidler; copy of a map drawn by Ac ko mok ki [Akutkomikimaan], a Blackfoot [Siksika] chief
fidler-large-HBCA-E3-2-225.caption: A copy of map first drawn in the snow by Ac Ko Mok Ki, a Siksika leader, in the winter of 1801, which represented nearly 200,000 square miles of the North American continent.
fidler-large-HBCA-E3-2-225.creditLine: Hudson's Bay Company Archives, Archives of Manitoba, Peter Fidler journals of exploration and survey, 1792-1806, G.1/25.
fidler-large-HBCA-E3-2-225.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Hudson's Bay Company Archives.
fidler-large-HBCA-E3-2-225.source: Hudson's Bay Company Archives, Archives of Manitoba

placeholder-humboldt-sketch.title: Géographie des plantes près de l´équateur.
placeholder-humboldt-sketch.caption: A sketch of Humboldt's famed diagram of Chimborazo, created in the same year as Caldas's drawings.

placeholder-caldas-1803-1.title: Plano de nivelacion de algunas plantas
placeholder-caldas-1803-1.caption: An elevation profile of Chimborazo, created by the Colombian naturalist Francisco José de Caldas, that likely inspired Humboldt's famous visualization.

placeholder-caldas-1803-2.title: Plano de nivelacion de algunas plantas
placeholder-caldas-1803-2.caption: A second elevation profile of Chimborazo created by Caldas.

Geographie_der_Pflanzen_in_den_Tropen-Lä.artist: Alexander von Humboldt and A.G. Bonpland
Geographie_der_Pflanzen_in_den_Tropen-Lä.caption: Humboldt's famed diagram of the vegetation of Mount Chimborazo, created with Aimé Jacques Alexandre Bonpland.
Geographie_der_Pflanzen_in_den_Tropen-Lä.digitizedLine: Digitized by Leibniz-Institut für Länderkunde, Leipzig

Demasduit.title: Portrait of Demasduit (watercolor on ivory)
Demasduit.caption: An 1819 portrait of Demasduit painted by Lady Henrietta Martha Hamilton.
Demasduit.creditLine: Library and Archives Canada, Acc. No. 1977-14-1
Demasduit.digitizedLine: Digitized by Library and Archives Canada.

placeholder-phelps.title: Top of Chimborazo 21000 feet from the level of the Sea.
placeholder-phelps.caption: Illustrator Thirza Lee's recreation of Humboldt's "Top of Chimborazo" for Familiar Lectures on Botany, a botany textbook for young women.
placeholder-phelps.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library Company of Philadelphia, www.librarycompany.org.
placeholder-phelps.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library Company of Philadelphia.

placeholder-sketch4-original.title: Sketch IV
placeholder-sketch4-original.caption: The fourth in a series of sketches created by Shanawdithit, depicting the travels of Shanawdithit and her family in the final months before her capture.

placeholder-sketch2-original.title: Sketch II
placeholder-sketch2-original.caption: The second in a series of sketches created by Shanawdithit, depicting the events that transpired at Red Indian Lake over the course of several decades.

Willard-picture.title: Picture of nations or perspective sketch of the course of empire. To accompany Willard's Universal history in perspective.
Willard-picture.caption: Willard's picture of nations adopts the triangular form of Humboldt's Chimborazo diagram in order to represent the rise and fall of nations.
Willard-picture.creditLine: Image courtesy of the David Rumsey Map Collection, Cartography Associates.
Willard-picture.digitizedLine: Digitized by the David Rumsey Map Collection, Cartography Associates.

birch-bark-1841.title: "Map drawn by Indians on birch-bark and attached to a tree to show their route to others following them, found by Capt. Bainbrigge R. Engineers at the ridge between the Ottawa and Lake Huron. May 1841."
birch-bark-1841.caption: An Ojibwe kikaigon, or directional map, which was found pinned to a tree by a British surveyor, Captain Bainbridge. Banbridge reproduces the map, with notes and commends, below.

howley-sketch2.title: Sketch II
howley-sketch2.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Internet Archive.

howley-sketch4.title: Sketch IV
howley-sketch4.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Internet Archive.

placeholder-sarah sense BirchBark 400px.title: Birch Bark
placeholder-sarah sense BirchBark 400px.caption: Contempory artist Sarah Sense (Chitimacha/Choctaw) employs Native weaving techniques as a way to interrupt the process of knowledge extraction that is documented in the original 1841 map and redirect some of its meaning-making force.
